title: Particle diagram - best representation of solid KF

content.question: Of the following diagrams, which best represents the structure of solid <math alttext="K F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>KF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: The figure presents a diagram with 6 rows of positively and negatively charged ions, arranged in 6 columns, with the circles representing the ions touching each other. In rows 1 and 2, there are 2 negative ions, followed by 2 positive ions, which are followed by 2 negative ions. In rows 3 and 4, there are 2 positive ions, followed by 2 negative ions, which are followed by 2 positive ions. In rows 5 and 6, there are 2 negative ions, followed by 2 positive ions, which are followed by 2 negative ions.

The figure presents a diagram with 6 rows of positively and negatively charged ions, arranged in 6 columns, with the circles that represent the ions touching each other. Rows 1, 3, and 5 all begin with a positive ion and then alternate between negative and positive ions across each row. Rows 2, 4, and 6 all begin with a negative ion and then alternate between positive and negative ions across each row.

The figure presents a diagram with 6 rows of positively and negatively charged ions, arranged in 6 columns, with the circles representing the ions touching each other. Rows 1, 3, and 5 contain only positive ions. Rows 2, 4, and 6 contain only negative ions.
The figure presents a diagram consisting of 8 ions that are widely spaced. There are four positive ions and four negative ions randomly scattered throughout the diagram.

content.answer: The figure presents a diagram with 6 rows of positively and negatively charged ions, arranged in 6 columns, with the circles that represent the ions touching each other.
